thread.title: 'His job is to represent his electorate': Nationals MPs stand by party whip George Christensen
thread.title_full: 'His job is to represent his electorate': Nationals MPs stand by party whip George Christensen

author: Matthew Knott
title: 'His job is to represent his electorate': Nationals MPs stand by party whip George Christensen
text:
twitter TWEET More 
Nationals MPs say they are happy for controversial MP George Christensen to remain their party whip despite him again publicly toying with breaking away from the government. 
Mr Christensen last week penned a letter to Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull in which he said his support for the government could not be guaranteed without action on a local sugar industry stoush in his north Queensland electorate. Mr Christensen did not send the letter but provided details of its content to the media. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link Nationals MP George Christensen wrote a letter to Malcolm Turnbull demanding he take action on the sugar industry. Photo: Alex Ellinghausen 
In it he said his support for the government was contingent on Mr Turnbull announcing a mandatory code of conduct for the sugar industry by March 1, with penalties. 
Mr Christensen's repeated public doubts about being a member of the Coalition and threats to cross the floor have raised questions about his role as Chief Nationals Whip, a position that puts him in charge of enforcing party discipline. 
Queensland Liberal National Party MP Keith Pitt said sugar was an "extremely hot button" in Mr Christensen's electorate and that he was right to demand action for his constituents. 
"If you don't stand up for the people you represent you won't be representing them much longer," he said. Advertisement 
Frontbench Nationals MP Michael McCormack said Mr Christensen was "generally a team player". 
"His job is to represent his electorate first and foremost," he said. 
NSW Nationals senator John Williams said he had not picked up the sense in the party that Mr Christensen should be stripped of his whip role. 
Liberal National senator Barry O'Sullivan said he did not believe Nationals leader Barnaby Joyce should put Mr Christensen in a "straitjacket". 
"I think more politicians ought to get off their fat bony arses around the country and speak up about what's right for their people," he told the ABC. 
Mr Joyce travelled to far north Queensland on the weekend to meet cane farmers to discuss their ongoing dispute with international agribusiness Wilmar Sugar. 
On Sunday he visited Ayr, a town in Mr Christensen's electorate with the local MP and state opposition leader Tim Nicholls. 
Mr Christensen previously threatened to pull support for the government over the backpacker tax and to cross the floor to vote against the government's superannuation changes. Advertisement
